I suspect the problenm could that the filename is longer than 256 characters.
I also wonder if all file systems are able to create files using the special characters like command, dot and brackets.

It seems to me that we are in quite some troubles here, as simplifying the method name isn't so easy.
Maybe we have to change back to a single deprection file containing all the deprecation refactorings?

The signatures contain only valid characters, but can get quite long.

Since we never have to recreate the deprecated element from the script file name, but always have a lookup whether a certain binding has an associated script, we could simply use a hash of the signature.

Storing several refactoring sessions in one file cannot be easily done and makes it harder to quickly look for a script.

But what do you do if several methods get the same hash?

Regarding the hash idea: It will depends on the hash you're using, but if it is something cryptic, it will be very bad from the user standpoint (no way to find a deprecation script again)

According to Tom is the comma character not valid on linux.

What about keeping a deprecation file per type? Maybe we should also use a folder structure that mirrors the package structure. That way we are closest to the classfile layout and should be fine with file name lengths issues.

We have UI for the deprecation scripts which allows to add or delete deprecation scripts. The internal structure of the .deprecation folder does not have to be human-readable, similar to the .refactorings folder.
Collisions are very very rarely, depending on the hashing function used (eg. md5). It would therefore be easiest to use hashing, as this would eliminate problems with different filesystems as well.

Yes we have UI, but making it human processable is even better.
Having files like DEPRECATED-3123939462946482t591937.xml is not very nice.
Also makes it harder for us to debug.

As long as you can have conflicts, you also have to handle them.

Removing target milestone, since the feature is deferred.

Implementation should use names in the format <type>.<member>#<count> to make lookup performant and read 'comment' attribute of the refactoring session persisted in the script as input handle.
